facts.description: The very odd but fascinating Goose Creek tower may look like something right out of a Dr Seuss book, but it is very real. Located in the Alaskan wilderness, it looks like someone went and stacked a whole lot of log cabins on top of each other, which isn't really true. It's owner definitely has a wild imagination and an adventurous spirit - would you be adventurous enough to live in such a house!

facts.description: Kobe camel lives in the scorching hot and sandy desert. The desert sand can sometimes get so hot that Kobe has to jump up and down to give his toes a little relief from the heat. Kobe is a cheerful, fun-loving camel though, and does not complain. Instead, he makes all the other camels laugh by making up a funny, bouncy dance while trying to keep off the hot sand.

fact.description: The desert sand can sometimes get so hot that Kobe has to jump up and down to give his toes a little relief from the heat.

facts.description: Eucalyptus leaves are very tough and toxic. Fortunately koalas have a digestive system that can break down and digest the toxic leaves unharmed. Digesting the tough fibrous leaves requires a lot of energy, so when they are not eating they are sleeping in the nooks and forks of trees. Koalas can sleep for 18-20 hours a day!

Their name "koala" comes from an Aboriginal term meaning "no drink". Koalas were probably given this name because they rarely ever drink water. It is believed that koalas get almost all their moisture from the leaves they eat. However, they may drink water during times of drought when the leaves do not provide enough moisture.

Koalas do not usually make sounds, but they sometimes communicate with each other with noises that sound like a snore and they sometimes call out really loud. Their loud calls are known as "bellows". A koala's bellowing can travel up to about 1km (0.6 miles) in still air!

When males claim a new tree, they mark it with their scent by rubbing their chest glands against the trunk or a branch. They may also occasionally dribble urine on the tree trunk. Koalas are known to sniff the base of a tree before climbing, and this kind of scent marking is probably done to let other koalas know that the tree is taken.

Koalas are tree-climbing, tree-hugging cuddly critters native to Australia. They have big round ears and oval noses. They are usually slate-grey or reddish brown in colour. Their fur may look soft but it is actually quite coarse, like wool, and is waterproof, which keeps them dry when it rains. Adult koalas are about 60-85cm (2-3ft) tall, and weigh about 14kg (30lb).

Koalas are often referred to as "koala bears". This is because when the first Europeans arrived in Australia, they thought koalas were bears due to their bear-like appearance, but they are not actually bears. Koalas are marsupials, or animals that have a pouch to carry their young, and their correct name is just "koala".

A baby koala, which is called a joey, is the size of a jellybean and weighs less than 1 gram at birth. When a joey is born, it immediately climbs up to its mother's pouch. A new born joey is blind and earless, and it uses its strong sense of touch and smell, as well as natural instinct, to find its way.
Koalas are not very social animals and spend just about 15 minutes a day on social behaviours. They do not normally visit another koalas home trees unless they are breeding.

Koalas are mostly nocturnal, which means that they are awake at night and asleep during the day. They may however, also sleep for part of the night, and they also occasionally move around during the day.

A joey grows and develops in the pouch for around six months. When it is bigger and stronger it rides on its mother's back for another six months, using the pouch only to feed. The average lifespan of a koala in the wild is 10-14 years.
The closest relative of koalas are wombats. Koalas are good swimmers, but they tire very quickly. If they cannot find an easy way to climb out of the water, they will eventually drown.

Koalas spend their time either eating or sleeping. They are big eaters and can consume up to 1kg (2.2lb) of eucalyptus leaves in a day! But they are also fussy eaters and will only select the most nutritious and tasty leaves to eat.

The koala's main habitat is the eucalyptus forests of southeastern and eastern Australia. Koalas are arboreal animals, which means they live in trees, and Eucalyptus trees are both their home and their source of food. They very rarely come down from the trees and if they do it is usually in search of another tree to climb.

A koala walks and climbs using all its four legs. They have two thumbs on each front paw. These thumbs or digits make their grip very strong and they can easily climb trees, hang on to branches and grab food. They also use their thumbs to comb their fur. Koalas have fingerprints just like humans do, they are in fact the only other mammal, besides primates, to have fingerprints.

Habitat loss is the greatest threat to koalas today. Unfortunately, around 80% of the koala's habitat has been lost to human homes, drought, bushfires and diseases of the eucalyptus, like "dieback" which causes the trees to die. Although protected by law, koalas are today considered vulnerable to extinction because of habitat loss.

A koala's "home" consists of several trees called "home trees". They live in these trees and visit them regularly, and the area these home trees cover is called the koala's "home range". Each koala has its own home range, which may overlap with those of other koalas.

fact.description: Koalas spend their time either eating or sleeping. They are big eaters and can consume up to 1kg (2.2lb) of eucalyptus leaves in a day!

facts.description: Tanzania's lake Rukwa is famous for the largest colony of great white pelicans with over 80,000 birds. Around 35 million kg (77 million lb) of fish is required every year to feed these pelicans. Most pelicans are done feeding by 8:00-9:00am and spend the rest of the day preening, bathing and roaming around on the sandbars or banks.

Great white pelicans have "totipalmate" feet, which means that each of their four toes are webbed and connect to each other. This along with their strong legs make them very fast and powerful swimmers. They can reach speeds of up to 6km/h (3.7 mi/h) in preparation for take-off.

Great white pelicans feed mainly on fish such as carp and cichlids, but will also eat small invertebrates. They also eat crustaceans, tadpoles, turtles and even chicks of other birds. When food is scarce, pelicans may also eat ducklings and seagulls and will also steal prey from other birds. They also accept handouts from humans.

Great white pelicans are powerful fliers too. When migrating they can fly continuously for a whole day and night and can cover distances of up to 480km (300 miles) without stopping. Pelicans make a spectacular sight when flying as they often fly in a V-formation.

The great white pelican is white in colour with black and grey primary wing feathers. Its face and feet are yellow in colour. It has an impressively long and straight bill that is blue and yellow on top and yellow below where the pouch is. The tip of the bill is hooked and red in colour. It has a short tail and short legs with webbed feet.

The great white pelican is not under any serious threat. The main threat they face is from humans who hunt them for their pouch which is made into tobacco bags, their skin which is made into leather and their faeces which is used as fertiliser. The fat of young pelicans is also converted into oil that is used in traditional medicines in Asia.

Pelicans are very social birds that breed and live together in large colonies. A group of pelicans is called a "pod". Their ideal habitat includes alkaline or freshwater lakes, marshes, swamps or deltas. They prefer warm, shallow water where there is plenty of fish and where there is plenty of grass or reeds along the banks.

The great white pelican is the biggest of all the pelican species and it is also one of world's largest flying birds. It can be found in the warm temperate and tropical regions of Africa, Asia and Europe.

Pelicans like to bathe by dipping their head and body in water while flapping their wings. They then spread out their wings to dry. They also gape or spread out their wings when it gets hot as a form of thermoregulation.

Great white pelicans are about 1.4-1.7m (4.5-5.5ft) long and weigh between 5-15kg (11-33lb). They have a very wide wingspan of up to 3.6m (11.8ft). Males are slightly larger than females and have slightly longer bills too. A male's bill is around 35-47cm (13-18in) long, while a female's bill is around 29-40cm (11-15in) long.

Pelicans often fish cooperatively in groups, something that's quite rare amongst birds. About 8-12 pelicans form a semi-circle and force fish into a corner in shallow water. They then dip their heads into the water, scoop up fish in their large bills, tilt their bills up and swallow the fish whole. Each pelican eats about 1.2-1.4kg (2.6-3.1lb) of fish daily.

Great white pelicans are generally silent birds. During the breeding season, however, when they are nesting they often make a low, hoarse display call. Wild dogs such as coyotes and wild cats are the natural predators of pelicans.

Pelicans build their nests on the ground and females lay an average of 2 eggs at a time, which are incubated for 29-36 days. The chicks are grey and have dark flight feathers. Both parents care for their young. The chicks learn to fly and hunt by about 3 months and reach maturity at 3-4 years of age.

The pelican's large pouch, also called the gular pouch, is made of extremely flexible fibrous skin that can expand and contract. Pelicans use their bill and pouch like a fishing net. When they catch prey, they drain away any water before swallowing the prey. The pouch has a capacity for 13 litres (3 gallons) of water, or up to 4kg (9lb) of fish.

The great white pelican is also called the eastern white pelican, rosy pelican and white pelican. Its scientific name is Pelecanus onocrotalus, and it belongs to the bird family Pelecanidae, which are large water birds with long beaks or bills and a large, stretchy throat pouch. It is the national bird of Romania.

During the breeding season, the great white pelican's chest and throat feathers may become pinkish or yellowish orange in colour. The face colour may also change to pinkish for the male and yellowish orange for the female.
